protocol_name: DNA preparation of Amorphophallus paeoniifolius for SSR evaluation
protocol_name_html: DNA preparation of Amorphophallus paeoniifolius for SSR evaluation
description: The corms and leaves of elephant foot yams (Amorphophallus paeoniifolius (Dennst.) Nicolson) are important foods in the local diet in many Asian regions. The crop has high productivity and wide agroecological adaptation and exhibits suitability for the agroforestry system. Although the plant is assumed to reproduce via panmixia, a comprehensive study on the genetic background across regions to enhance wider consumer palatability is still lacking. Here, ten informative microsatellites were analyzed in 29 populations across regions in India, Indonesia and Thailand to understand the genetic diversity, population structure and distribution to improve breeding and conservation programs. The genetic diversity was high among and within regions. Some populations exhibited excess heterozygosity and bottlenecking. Pairwise FST indicated very high genetic differentiation across regions (FST = 0.274), and the Asian population was unlikely to be panmictic. Phylogenetic tree construction grouped the populations according to country of origin with the exception of the Medan population from Indonesia. The current gene flow was apparent within the regions but was restricted among the regions. The present study revealed that Indonesia and Thailand populations could be alternative centers of the gene pool, together with India. Consequently, regional action should be incorporated in genetic conservation and breeding efforts to develop new varieties with global acceptance.
manuscript_citation: Santosa E, Lian CL, Sugiyama N, Misra RS, Boonkorkaew P, Thanomchit K (2017) Population structure of elephant foot yams (Amorphophallus paeoniifolius (Dennst.) Nicolson) in Asia. PLoS ONE 12(6): e0180000. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0180000
guidelines:
Leaf collection

Leaf of Amorphophallus paeoniifolius was collected by using dry method. 

 

DNA extraction 

DNA was extracted using the modified CTAB method from the original protocol described by Lian et al. [2002]. Modification was required because the leaf of A. paeoniifolius contained glucomannan, a kind of high molecular of carbohydrate that difficult to dissolve in the water. Presence of glucomannan in the solution might cause DNA impurity, resulting on low PCR amplification. To separate DNA from the glucomannan, we used fishing method. Glucomannan pellet commonly transparent but still visible to be observed at the bottom of the extraction tube after we added water. After about 40 minutes, and DNA was expected dissolve completely, we pick up the glucomannan by fishing. For SSR analysis, DNA from approximately one gram of dry leaf was then preserved in a final volume of 200 µL of water and was stored at -30 °C until ready for use.

 

SSR primer optimation and reagent

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was carried out in a 5-µL tube. For large sample, we recommend to use PCR plate with 48 wells. A 0.5-μL aliquot of extract was used in each PCR amplification to approximately contain 5-20 ng of DNA. SSR marker and DNA were amplified with a PCR reagent mix of 0.5 µM of the Forward primer, 0.1 µm of the Reverse primer tailed with U-19 (Fastac Co, Tokyo-Japan), 0.5 µM of the U-19 primer labeled with Texas Red, 0.2 mM of each dNTP, 1× PCR buffer (Mg2+ free, Applied Biosystems), 2.5 mM MgCl2, and 0.5 U of Ampli Taq Gold DNA polymerase (Applied Biosystems).

components.data: Harvest a fresh leaf of Amorphophallus paeoniifolius at green stage.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Harvest a fresh leaf of Amorphophallus paeoniifolius at green stage.

components.data: Glucomannan pellet commonly transparent but still visible to be observed at the bottom of the extraction tube after adding water. After about 40 minutes, and DNA is expected dissolve completely, pick up the glucomannan by fishing.

source_data.description: Glucomannan pellet commonly transparent but still visible to be observed at the bottom of the extraction tube after adding water. After about 40 minutes, and DNA is expected dissolve completely, pick up the glucomannan by fishing.

components.data: Perform the PCR using hot start to increase reproducibility of the product.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Perform the PCR using hot start to increase reproducibility of the product.

components.data: Finally, mix 1.5 μL of the PCR product with 3.5 μL of loading dye, denature using the Thermal cycle TAKARA for five minutes at 95 °C, and then was place on ice immediately for five minutes prior to loading.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Finally, mix 1.5 μL of the PCR product with 3.5 μL of loading dye, denature using the Thermal cycle TAKARA for five minutes at 95 °C, and then was place on ice immediately for five minutes prior to loading.

components.data: Clean the leaf initially both abaxial and adaxial sides using moist tissue paper.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Clean the leaf initially both abaxial and adaxial sides using moist tissue paper.

components.data: Then, remove the leaf midrib/vein using a sterile knife.
components.name: Description

components.data: Before storing in the silica gel, cut the leaf into small sections facilitating quick drying.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Before storing in the silica gel, cut the leaf into small sections facilitating quick drying.

components.data: One gram of fresh leaf requires approximately 20-30 gram of silica gel, and store in air tight box.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: One gram of fresh leaf requires approximately 20-30 gram of silica gel, and store in air tight box.

components.data: For SSR analysis, preserve DNA from approximately one gram of dry leaf in a final volume of 200 µL of water and store at -30 °C until ready for use.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: For SSR analysis, preserve DNA from approximately one gram of dry leaf in a final volume of 200 µL of water and store at -30 °C until ready for use.

components.data: Perform the PCR as follows: one cycle of 9 min at 94 °C followed by 30 s at the locus-specific annealing temperature (Ta) plus 1 min at 72 °C, and then 38 cycles of 30 s at 94 °C, 30 s at the locus-specific Ta plus 1 min at 72 °C, followed by one cycle of 30 s at 94 °C, 30 s at the locus-specific Ta plus 5 min extension at 72 °C, and ending at 4 °C.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Perform the PCR as follows: one cycle of 9 min at 94 °C followed by 30 s at the locus-specific annealing temperature (Ta) plus 1 min at 72 °C, and then 38 cycles of 30 s at 94 °C, 30 s at the locus-specific Ta plus 1 min at 72 °C, followed by one cycle of 30 s at 94 °C, 30 s at the locus-specific Ta plus 5 min extension at 72 °C, and ending at 4 °C.

source_data.annotation: In the optimation step, we mixed some SSR primers that had similar Ta and the target bands that had distant allele size.

components.data: Load two-microliter aliquots onto a 6% denaturing polyacrylamide gel and were run using the SQ-5500 sequencer (Hitachi Co., Tokyo). The band patterns were analyzed with FRAGYLS ver. 2 (Hitachi Electronics Engineering Co., Japan).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Load two-microliter aliquots onto a 6% denaturing polyacrylamide gel and were run using the SQ-5500 sequencer (Hitachi Co., Tokyo). The band patterns were analyzed with FRAGYLS ver. 2 (Hitachi Electronics Engineering Co., Japan).

source_data.annotation: Two bands were considered different alleles if the difference was larger than two base pairs.
source_data.thread_text: Two bands were considered different alleles if the difference was larger than two base pairs.
source_data.body: Two bands were considered different alleles if the difference was larger than two base pairs.

components.data: Two bp different is a matter of technical procedure, not related to nucleotide repeat motif. Determine allele size using FRAGYLS software.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Two bp different is a matter of technical procedure, not related to nucleotide repeat motif. Determine allele size using FRAGYLS software.

source_data.annotation: The software has automatically detected homo or hetero alleles, successfully in most individuals. In some cases, hetero alleles had only one base in different of the first and the second alleles. In this case, we checked the size manually considering the bands quality and concluded the alleles size as homo or hetero to avoid bias estimate of FRAGYLS software. Theoretically, we concluded the hetero alleles if 2 or more bp in different.
source_data.thread_text: The software has automatically detected homo or hetero alleles, successfully in most individuals.
